story.headline: Lake Chad Has Shrunk by 90% Since the 1960s
story.summary: Once one of Africa's largest lakes, Lake Chad has lost approximately 90% of its surface area due to climate change, overuse of water resources, and prolonged drought cycles in the Sahel region.
story.climateImpact: Rising temperatures increase evaporation and reduce rainfall in the Lake Chad Basin, accelerating the lake's decline and triggering cascading humanitarian crises.
causeEffect: Shifting rainfall patterns reduce inflows from tributaries
Shrinking lake devastates fishing communities and agriculture
Water scarcity fuels regional conflict and displacement
story.scaleContext: Over 30 million people across four countries (Chad, Niger, Nigeria, Cameroon) depend on the Lake Chad Basin. The lake shrank from 25,000 km² in 1963 to under 2,500 km² today.
story.outlook: Without coordinated water management and climate adaptation, Lake Chad could functionally disappear, displacing millions and destabilizing the entire Sahel region.
